issue.body:
From what I was able to figure out through my own testing, there are some issues with winmm for joystick handling on Windows 8.1.  Its difficult to find any reliable data on winmm and the consensus is that it was replaced with directinput.

This was tested on WIndows 8.1 Pro x64
The symptoms has to do with connecting Xbox 360 wireless controllers while a process is running.  I only have 3 controllers so I'm not sure on the behavior of a 4th controller.

Repro steps:
1. Start windows process
2. Connect controller 0, verify receiving input correctly
3. Step 2 with controller 1
4. Connect controller 2.

At this point, something odd happens.  glfw creates separate pointers for the buttons, presence, and axes all correctly and all the data being passed into winmm are correct.  But the data retrieved by the windows functions for controller 2 is ACTUALLY the data from controller 1!

There's some sort of weird overlap that happens with the windows joystick pointers where, when requesting data from the 3rd connected controller, it returns data from the 2nd.

This behavior does not occur if all 3 controllers are connected before the process is started!  I've been tackling this for the better part of a week and my conclusion is that WIndows 8 broke winmm in this specific case.

This issue isnt with glfw per se, I am mostly interested in hearing any feedback from anyone with more knowledge of winmm or, especially, someone able to reproduce this issue on their own.

Is it possible to upgrade to dinput?  Is that planned?  I'm interested in hearing the possibilities! 

Thank you for taking a look!

issue.title: Expose Xbox 360 controller player number

repository.name: glfw
repository.description: A multi-platform library for OpenGL, OpenGL ES, Vulkan, window and input

issue.body: A controller detection bug happens when the game has more than one controller and player 1 unplugs their controller while the game is running. When they restart the game (with only player 2 still plugged in) GLFW registers player 2's controller as Joystick_1. Then when player 1 re-plugs their controller in they make player 2's controller end up registering to Joystick_2 as well. Thus making player 2's controller registered to both Joystick_1 and Joystick_2 leaving player 1's controller not registered to any Joysticks. Is there a way that GLFW can grab the controller's player index from the xbox drivers? Or will I have to settle for disabling and re-enabling the xbox drivers when I shut down the game just to make it sort of work?

However to my surprise it isn't being recognized by GLFW. I have yet to try half of my other controllers but I did try debugging with the Shield controller and I can't find anything. So I thought at least I'd let people over here know about this issue, and later (after I get some sleep) I will be checking with the 8 or so other pc game controllers I have to see if they give the same outcome.
I will post back here if I find out anymore. Thanks in advanced.

issue.title: Joystick polling is slower than expected

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Bug reports and bugfix pull requests

milestone.title: None
milestone.description: This is for issues that do not belong to any milestone, to tell them apart from un-reviewed issues closed by the submitter.

repository.name: glfw
repository.description: A multi-platform library for OpenGL, OpenGL ES, Vulkan, window and input

issue.body:
We do input polling and game state updating at a fairly high rate in our game, at 250Hz. Joystick polling seems to be significantly slower than expected, which causes problems for us.

With no joysticks connected, calling glfwJoystickPresent() for all 16 joystick slots takes 0.116ms on average to complete, totaling 29ms per 1000 second.

Calling glfwGetJoystickAxes() and glfwGetJoystickButtons() for each of the 16 joysticks (without having any connected though) takes an average of 0.189 ms, totaling 47.25ms per second. This is a significant chunk of our total frame-time as we have a budget around 2-3 ms for each update.

This is further incentive to add callback support and/or add threading support to joystick polling. Threading support is in my opinion preferred and should also be easier to implement.

body:
Hi, I just noticed this issue myself. I've been using GLFW for quite some time, in side projects and through [Monkey](https://github.com/blitz-research/monkey). If this is still an issue, I'd be happy to add XInput support. I've already written several dynamic-linking setups, similar to [what Dolphin does](https://github.com/dolphin-emu/dolphin/blob/49ea15b9502d98f08c47429ce93827073cefdaad/Source/Core/InputCommon/ControllerInterface/XInput/XInput.cpp#L77). Only, you know, it doesn't tend to break _as much_. I'm not very familiar with DirectInput, however. That being said, with both WinMM and XInput, what would be a benefit of supporting DirectInput? Also, what would be the best way to structure a change like this? Conditional support when compiling? Support WinMM as a fall-back?

Either way, I'm quite familiar with C and very familiar with C++. [This project](https://github.com/Regal-Internet-Brothers/IOSync/blob/1b70968e1fd85f031a9a159d2195899aeee73521/IOSync/src/devices/native/winnt/Real_XInput_Wrapper.cpp#L103), and [this project](https://github.com/Regal-Internet-Brothers/xinput/blob/bdd1590eea3bb8cefdcb58854c152f7915cb51e3/native/xinput.cpp#L303) both use function-pointers, 'LoadLibrary', and 'GetProcAddress'. They also support 'XInputGetStateEx' when available, meaning the guide button (Button 10) works.

If you're not interested, I understand. I'm also not the first guy to go to, where git is concerned.
